Version: Modernized Tanakh - Based on JPS 1917, Edited by Adam Cohn
Content: Issachar is a large-boned ass, Crouching down between the two folds.

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: If they did not have in them a handbreadth's space, whether there was a handbreadth's space between them or whether there was not a handbreadth's space between them, if there was impurity beneath

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And Haman said: Also, Queen Esther did not bring with the king to the feast that she made anyone but me; and tomorrow, too, I am invited by her with the king.

Version: Daf Shevui
Content: “And the king said to Queen Esther What is your requests? Even to the half of the kingdom, it shall be given you.” (Esther 5:6) “Half the kingdom” but not the whole kingdom. And not a thing which would divide the kingdom.What could that be? The building of the Temple.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Then Esther the queen, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote down all the acts of power, to confirm this second letter of Purim.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king returned from the palace garden to the house of the wine-feast; and Haman was fallen [(an angel had pushed him)] on the divan where Esther reclined. And the king said: Did you also come

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Say thou unto the king and to the queen-mother: ‘Sit ye down low; For your headtires are come down, Even your beautiful crown.’

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And Esther said: A man who is an oppressor and a foe, this wicked Haman! And Haman was confounded before the king and the queen.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king arose in his anger from the feast of wine to the palace garden, and Haman stood to beg his life of Queen Esther; for he saw that evil [i.e., hatred and the thirst for revenge] had been consummated against him by the king.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And King Achashverosh had said [(to Esther, in the beginning, through an intermediary)] and [now that he had learned that she was of royal lineage], he said [(directly)] to Queen Esther: Who is this, and where is he, who has presumed to do thus?

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king said to Esther also the second day of the feast of wine: What is your petition, Queen Esther, and it will be granted you. And what is your request? Until half the kingdom, and it shall be done.

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: "And the King said to Esther the Queen, 'In Shushan the capital, the Jews have killed..." Rabbi Abahu said, this teaches that an angel came and slapped him in his mouth.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king and Haman came to drink with Queen Esther.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And Pharaoh's goblet was in my hand. And I took the grapes and squeezed them into Pharaoh's goblet; and I placed the goblet on Pharaoh's hand.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And the thing became known to Mordecai, who told it unto Esther the queen; and Esther told the king thereof in Mordecai’s name.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the maidens of Esther and her eunuchs came and told her; and the queen was greatly shaken, and she sent garments to clothe Mordecai and to remove his sack from him, but he did not accept them.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And it was, when the king saw Queen Esther standing in the court, that she found favor in his eyes, and the king held out to Esther the golden sceptre which was in his hand, and Esther drew near, and she touched the head of the sceptre.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king said to her: What troubles you, Queen Esther, and what is your request? Until half the kingdom, and it shall be given you.

Version: Daf Shevui
Content: “And it was that when the king saw Esther the queen” (Esther 5:2): R. Yohanan said: Three ministering angels were appointed to help her at that moment; one to make her head erect, a second to endow her with charm and a third to stretch the sceptre.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And that ye may put difference between the holy and the common, and between the unclean and the clean;

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: Replace Vashti with another queen

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: to make a difference between the unclean and the clean, and between the living thing that may be eaten and the living thing that may not be eaten.

Version: Daf Shevui
Content: Abahu picks up on the strange repetition of the word “said.” He interprets that at first, Ahashverosh refused to speak directly to Esther, for he did not know her lineage. When she told him that she was of royal lineage, from the house of Saul, he spoke to her, addressing her as Queen Esther.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the king said to Queen Esther: In Shushan the capital, the Jews killed and destroyed five hundred men and the ten sons of Haman. In the other provinces of the king, what did they do? Now, what

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the children of Israel divested themselves of their adornment [which had been bequeathed them] at Mount Chorev.

Version: Daf Shevui
Content: What is the practical difference between them? The difference between them is who must bother [to sell the terumah].

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: To fulfill these days of Purim in their times, as instituted for them by Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther, and as they fulfilled in themselves and in their seed, the words of the fasts and their outcries.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And Queen Esther answered and she said: If I have found favor in your eyes, O king, and if it pleases the king, grant me my life as my petition [i.e., that I not be killed on the thirteenth of Adar

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: Then King Ahashverosh said, and he said to Esther the Queen..." Why is it 'he said and he said'? Rabbi Abahu said, in the beginning he spoke through an interpreter. Then, when she said to him 'I come from the house of Saul', he immediately 'said to Esther the Queen'.

Version: Tractate Berakot by A. Cohen, Cambridge University Press, 1921
Content: The following are between the sections, etc.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: Then the congregation shall judge between the slayer and the avenger according to these judgments,

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: The difference between them is [the ruling concerning] maidservants.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And the king loved Esther above all the women, and she obtained grace and favour in his sight more than all the virgins; so that he set the royal crown upon her head, and made her queen instead of Vashti.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And King Achashverosh said to Queen Esther and to Mordecai the Jew: Behold, I have given the house of Haman to Esther, and him have they hanged upon the gallows because he set his hand against the Jews.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: On that day, King Achashverosh gave Queen Esther the house of Haman, oppressor of the Jews; and Mordecai came before the king, for Esther had told him what he was to her [i.e., how he was related to her].
